instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All S5 no S0 and S0 enables
threads.message:
[U][B]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power[/B][/U]

[B]History[/B]
Liquid damage.

Replaced all visible and some no visaully bad components. Everything looks good now, been around this schematic a few times now going in circles.

[B]Meassurements[/B]
3V42 good
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
All S5 rails are good.
No S0 enables
No signal to <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All S5 no S0 and S0 enables
threads.message: Ok, it's spinning up now but only stays on for a moment sometimes... Other times it revs right up and stays on. I'll see if I can get it to ASD

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All S5 no S0 and S0 enables
threads.message: 3437 will cycle on/off  3 times before it will actually boot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All S5 no S0 and S0 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 5982"]3437 will cycle on/off 3 times before it will actually boot.[/QUOTE]

Yes I know. I'm talking about after POST. Sorry, just looked at what I wrote again and it does come over like I didn't know that but fear not, i'm only actually half moron :)
I do at least have it spinning up now but no chime and no backlight or image so I'll deal with that next. The problem was (and always is from this place) some F* div tech does not fix the problem and adds to it by soldering the wrong value resistors decades above or below what is ment to be there so I end up spending ages removing mistakes.

They all come from a "refurb center" that seems to do more DE-furb than refurb

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All S5 no S0 and S0 enables
threads.message: Use a USB mouse to check for USB initialization, if it lights up it is a good indicator the board is working. Also CPU Vcore must of course first be there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All S5 no S0 and S0 enables
threads.message: Ok thanks I will try plug in a mouse and check for light. Will check vcore too. will fan ever spin up without all vcore rails?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All S5 no S0 and S0 enables
threads.message: Ok, we have light on the mouse. Now to figure out why it's no chime

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All S5 no S0 and S0 enables
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All S5 no S0 and S0 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6032"]You do a PRAM reset[/QUOTE]

Tried that but not responding keyboard and track pad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> All S5 no S0 and S0 enables
threads.message: Use external keyboard and disconnect the internal trackpad.
